keyTakeAways: Peru's President Jose Jeri declared a 30-day state of emergency in Lima and Callao to combat rising crime.
The emergency measure, approved by the Council of Ministers, allows for the deployment of armed forces and police to maintain public order.
The declaration follows deadly protests that left one person dead and over 100 injured, highlighting public unrest over crime.
President Jeri, who took office earlier this month after the ousting of Dina Boluarte, has made combating crime a top priority.

This is not the first such emergency in Peru; former President Dina Boluarte declared a similar 30-day emergency in March, though experts argue such repeated measures have not effectively reduced crime.
The emergency response comes amid a protest movement led by young people from 'Generation Z' demanding action against rising crime.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Peru’s President Jose Jeri has declared a 30-day state of emergency in the capital Lima and the neighboring province of Callao to address a surge in crime, following deadly protests that left one person dead and over 100 injured. The emergency, approved by the Council of Ministers and effective just after midnight on October 21, 2025, authorizes the deployment of armed forces and police to restore public order. This move follows Jeri’s inauguration after the ousting of former President Dina Boluarte and comes amid growing public pressure from young people in the 'Generation Z' group who demand stronger measures against crime. The declaration echoes a previous emergency imposed by Boluarte in March, though experts argue that repeated such measures have not effectively reduced crime levels, raising questions about the long-term efficacy of emergency responses.
title: Peru declares 30-day state of emergency in Lima to tackle rising crime
